atAGlance.mustRegister: Anyone convicted of a qualifying sexual offense (or equivalent from another jurisdiction) who lives, works, or studies in Tennessee must register within 48 hours of establishing residence, employment, or enrollment. See TCA §40-39-203.
atAGlance.initialDeadline: 48 hours to register after establishing presence (excluding weekends and holidays).
atAGlance.verificationCadence: Violent sexual offenders: quarterly (March, June, September, December). Other sexual offenders: annually within 7 days before or after birthday.
atAGlance.primaryMethod: In-person reporting with local law enforcement; data entered into the TBI registry. Fingerprints, palm prints, and photographs required.
topGotchas: All changes (address, job, school, phone, email) must be updated within 48 hours.
Creating or changing online usernames or emails must be reported within 3 days.
Failure to register or update is a felony.

whoMustRegister: Individuals convicted of any qualifying sexual offense listed under TCA §40-39-202(20), including offenses against minors, sexual battery, rape, child exploitation, and federal or out-of-state equivalents.
deadlinesReporting: Register within 48 hours of residence, job, or school change.
Return for annual or quarterly verification as required.
Report name, address, employment, or school changes within 48 hours.
Report new online accounts, usernames, or emails within 3 days.
verificationInPerson: Fingerprinting and updated photos are required periodically.
residencyPresence: Registrants with minor victims may not live or work within 1,000 feet of schools, parks, playgrounds, or daycare centers. Living within 1,000 feet of a victim or their family is prohibited.
employmentEducationInternet: Cannot work or volunteer with direct, unsupervised access to minors.
Must report job or school changes within 48 hours.
Cannot portray characters (e.g., Santa, clown) to attract minors.
publicWebsiteExposure: The public site lists offender details, offenses, addresses, and photos. Victim identities are excluded.
Some registrants (juvenile or limited-duration) may not appear online.
travelInterstate: Moving out of TN: notify authorities 48 hours before leaving.
International travel: provide at least 21 days’ notice (or as soon as possible for emergencies).
visitingTraveling: Visiting 14 days in a year (or 4 in a month) triggers registration as a secondary residence.
Travelers should register within 48 hours if thresholds are met.
complianceEnforcement: Failure to register, report, or update is a Class E felony with mandatory minimum jail terms: 90 days (first), 180 days (second), and 1 year (third or more). Each day of non-compliance may count separately.
reliefPaths: Sexual offenders may request removal after 10 years of compliance.
Violent or repeat offenders are lifetime registrants.
Expungement of the conviction (rare) results in immediate removal.
specialPopulations: Juvenile offenders: may be required to register only if tried as adults.
Multiple offenders may not reside in the same dwelling (limit: 2).
costs: Annual or quarterly registration fee up to $150.
State-issued offender ID card required; free if indigent.
Failure to obtain proper ID within 60 days is a felony.

summary: Tennessee uses very short timelines. Forty-eight hours means two business days at most (weekends and legal holidays don’t count). Register or update in person with the local sheriff or police, and bring ID.
If you visit or move to Tennessee and meet the presence thresholds, plan to register rather than risk a felony charge.
watchOuts: Missing a 48-hour update for an address, job, or school change can trigger arrest. Put these deadlines in your phone calendar.
Creating or changing an email, screen name, or social handle must be reported within three days. That is a separate rule from the 48-hour changes.
atAGlance.validationNote: Verified with TCA §40-39-203 and TBI Sex Offender Registry. Content validated with the help of AI; please contact SOLAR if you find something outdated.

summary: Register within 48 hours of establishing residence, employment, or school enrollment. Report any change in those items within 48 hours as well.
Report new or changed emails, usernames, or online identifiers within three days.
watchOuts: Homeless status requires monthly, in-person reporting. If you obtain housing, update within 48 hours.
If you are moving out of Tennessee, provide your new address at least 48 hours before departure.
deadlinesReporting.validationNote: See TCA §40-39-203 (deadlines and reporting windows).

summary: Violent sexual offenders verify quarterly (March, June, September, December). Other sexual offenders verify annually within a seven-day window around their birthday.
Expect fingerprints and a new photo as needed; bring state-issued ID.
watchOuts: Fees (up to $150) may be due at verification; indigent status may reduce other ID costs but not the verification fee.
If you miss a quarterly or annual appointment, call the registering agency immediately and appear in person to mitigate consequences.
verificationInPerson.validationNote: Intervals and procedures summarized from TCA §40-39-203 and TBI guidance.

summary: Primary residence is established after five consecutive days in Tennessee. Secondary residence is met at 14 days in a year or four days in a month.
If you meet a threshold, register within 48 hours at the local sheriff or police department. For international travel, give 21 days’ notice when possible.
watchOuts: Hotel stays count toward presence thresholds. Keep records of check-in/checkout dates.
Your home state may require advance travel notice even if Tennessee does not for very short trips.
visitingTraveling.validationNote: Presence thresholds and duties drawn from TCA §40-39-203 and TBI practice; international travel expectations align with federal International Megan’s Law.

summary: If the victim was under 18, Tennessee imposes 1,000-foot buffers around schools, parks, playgrounds, and childcare facilities for residence and work.
All registrants are prohibited from living within 1,000 feet of the victim or the victim’s immediate family.
watchOuts: Measure from property line to property line; a site that seems far enough may still be within 1,000 feet.
Local rules or probation/parole conditions can be stricter than the statute.

summary: Do not work or volunteer in roles with direct, unsupervised contact with minors if your victim was a minor.
Report any change in employment or student status within 48 hours; report new online identifiers within three days.
watchOuts: Some roles are categorically prohibited (for example, performing to attract children, ice-cream truck vending).
Schools and many employers will run checks; confirm compliance before accepting a role.
employmentEducationInternet.validationNote: Restrictions and reporting windows drawn from TCA §40-39-211 and §40-39-203.

summary: Non-compliance is a Class E felony with mandatory minimum jail time that increases for repeat violations.
Any period of non-compliance pauses eligibility timelines for removal from the registry.
watchOuts: Each day late can be a separate offense in some contexts.
Keep dated proof of submissions (receipt, certified mail, stamped forms) to resolve disputes.
complianceEnforcement.validationNote: Penalties and tolling summarized from TCA §40-39-204 and §40-39-207.

summary: Sexual offenders (non-violent) may apply to TBI for removal after 10 years of clean compliance from completion of sentence.
Violent sexual offenders and repeat offenders are lifetime registrants with no early removal.
watchOuts: Any disqualifying new offense or documented non-compliance will result in denial.
If denied for non-compliance (not a new offense), you may reapply after five years.
reliefPaths.validationNote: Process and eligibility from TCA §40-39-207 and TBI practice.
